sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: This document provides a concise overview of the steps you'll take to generate a portal instance with the JA-SIG uPortal framework. We'll assume you have extensive, recent experience with server-side Java application development and have an intimate understanding of the operating system and configuration of the computer system on which you are attempting to install the portal.

The first thing you must decide is how you're going to work with the uPortal framework to produce a portal instance at your site. Releases of uPortal come in two forms: The quick start releases and the standalone source code.

sect2.title: Choosing A Release of uPortal
sect2.para: Making the choice as to which of the two major kinds of uPortal releases is right for you involves examining what you're trying to immediately achieve. If you're just attempting to get started with uPortal in order to see what features it supports, what it requires in terms of personnel, hardware and software support or to assess how it compares to other portal vendor's products, then the Quick Start Releases are for you. If you're trying to get a portal instance configured and installed for production use on your campus, or if you're a developer who requires an instance of the portal so that you can develop content or applications for use with your campus' portal, then you'll probably work with the uPortal sources as they are released from the JA-SIG CVS repository. Compiling uPortal from source is the best way to make sure you can get your instance working with your particular development and deployment environments.

sect3.title: The uPortal Quick Start Releases
sect3.para: The Quick Start releases are assembled so they can be downloaded and run with a minimum of effort, and they include all the software necessary to run an instance of the portal except an operating system, JVM and web browser. Assuming that you already have these three items installed, you can start using the portal instance provided with a Quick Start release just a few minutes after you complete the download processs.

JA-SIG produces the Quick Start releases to make it easy for campuses to evaluate the uPortal framework and decide if it meets their needs. JA-SIG realizes that some university IT departments operate in a demo-driven management decision-making environment and that IT staff who are attempting to make a rational choice among portal vendors often have to compete with slick sales presentations from marketing and sales staff from major software vendors. The Quick Start releases enable those IT staff members to get a demo of a uPortal -based portal going quickly so that managers can get a better idea of how uPortal stacks up against products from those vendors.

The Quick Start releases aren't appropriate if your intent is to produce a production portal instance for deployment on your campus. For production use, you're highly likely to want to customize the look and feel of the portal to reflect the published style guide for websites at your institution. You're also likely to already have a web application infrastructure (meaning a web server, Java servlet/JSP container, relational database management system, directory server, ERPs, etc.) that you want your portal to utilize so that you leverage existing information systems. Although you could use the Quick Start releases as a starting point and customize the portal instance that ships until it meets your needs, ultimately you will spend more time than if you started with the standalone sources from the source code repository. (see , below).

sect3.title: The uPortal Source Code
sect3.para: As an open source project, JA-SIG makes the full source code for the uPortal framework available to member institutions at no cost. While working with the standalone uPortal sources directly involves more up-front compilation and configuration work to produce a working portal instance, it provides you with the maximum amount of flexibility in producing what you deploy, either in production for use by end-users on your campus or in development for use by your content producers or application programmers.

Working with the uPortal sources isn't the best method of producing a portal instance if you just want to get an instance of a portal up and running quickly to kick the tires, see what it looks like or see what features it supports. If you're just attempting to evaluate uPortal, you can do so in less time than compiling the uPortal sources requires by downloading and installing the latest Quick Start release(skip the next section and see , below).

sect2.title: Prerequisites for compiling and installing uPortal From Source
sect2.para:
In order to compile the uPortal framework from source to produce an installation of a portal at your site, you must first have some tools installed on the computer you plan to use to run the portal on. Before proceeding with the following instructions, obtain and install the following:
A CVS client for your operating system.
A JDK 1.2.2 or higher Java Virtual Machine. uPortal has been tested extensively using the Sun and IBM Virtual Machines.
A copy of Ant. Ant is a build tool for Java developed by the Apache Jakarta Project.
A Java Servlet Container which is complaint with the Servlets 2.2 specification. uPortal has been tested extensively using the Apache Jakarta Project's Tomcat Servlet Container and web server, but any Servlets 2.2 compliant container should work.
A fourth generation web browser. Netscape Navigator 4.x or Internet Explorer 4.x as a minimum. Mozilla or Internet Explorer 5.x should also work fine.
A relational database management system (RDBMS) with a JDBC 2.0-complaint driver. the uPortal development team uses HypersonicSQL to facilitate development, but some campuses deploy a uPortal instance with IBM DB2, Oracle 8i, MS SQL server and others. Any RDBMS with a JDBC 2.0 compliant driver should work with some additional setup and configuration work.
A copy of the Apache Jakarta project's Xalan XSLT processor.
Once you have these tools available on your machine, you can proceed with compiling and configuring a portal instance from the JA-SIG uPortal sources. Skip the next section and see , below.

sect1.title: Downloading and installing a uPortal Quick Start Release
sect1.para: The uPortal Quick Start releases only require that you have a 1.2.2 or later Java Virtual Machine and a web browser installed on the computer system that you wish to run the portal on. Assuming you already have those items installed, you can proceed with the following procedure for downloading and installing the Quick Start release. The procedure assumes you're going to install and operate the portal on a UNIX-like operating system, but because uPortal, as a Java-based framework, is platform-independant, you should be able to follow the instructions for a windows-based system simply by substituting the windows equivalent paths and DOS shell commands in place of the described UNIX paths and tcsh commands.

step.para: As of this writing, the most current Quick Start release is LaJolla.zip, which was released in May 2001. You can obtain the release from the JA-SIG website, located at http://www.ja-sig.org/. Download LaJolla.zip from that link to your local filesystem. Once the download is complete, you should have 9.8 MB file.
Unizip your copy of LaJolla.zip using the unzip utility: unzip LaJolla.zip
Obtain a directory listing: cd LaJolla; ls
Verify that you have the following files and subdirectories:

sect1.title: Configuring and Compiling the JA-SIG uPortal Sources
sect1.para: The uPortal development team uses a CVS repository to maintain the various revisions to the source code. Access to this repository requires a username and password, which you'll have to obtain by first registering with the JA-SIG Clearinghouse. The login name and password you set here will be the login and password you will use for accessing the JA-SIG CVS repository.
Once you register, use your CVS client to access the source code repository.
